metadata.title: POSTDATA|Use-Case Cantigas de Santa Maria for Singers
metadata.repertory: Cantigas de Santa Maria for Singers
metadata.description: A test of the Domain Model v1.0 with a resource from the database CSM for Singers - see source
metadata.comments: Since the images of the musical transcriptions are created on-the-fly, we have used the link provided for the images even if they were not URL. We know it is not a URl but the idea was to show that the model works.

dataProperty.name: editedContent
dataProperty.value: Esta é como Santa María fez cobrar a Teófilo a carta que fezéra cono démo, u se tornou séu vassalo.

dataProperty.name: notes
dataProperty.value: The Escorial "codice princeps" (principal codex, signature j.b.2), held in the Real Biblioteca de San Lorenzo de El Escorial outside Madrid. Also known in Spanish as the códice de los músicos—the musicians' codex—due to the well-known and oft-reproduced miniatures of performers and their instruments that appear before each of the Cantigas de Loor. This is by far the largest of the manuscripts, though modest in decoration compared to [T] and [F]. It contains the prologues and 406 of the cantigas, nine of which are repeated with mostly minor variations, and provides the basis for Mettmann's numbering scheme, which I use on this website.

dataProperty.name: notes
dataProperty.value: the Escorial "codice rico" (rich codex), also in the El Escorial library, known as [T] from its manuscript signature T.j.1. Contains the prologues and 195 of the cantigas (originally 203, but eight are missing due to the loss of folios), roughly corresponding to the first half of [E].

dataProperty.name: notes
dataProperty.value: the "Toledo" codex, now in the National Library of Madrid. It includes 129 cantigas, which are apparently amongst the oldest in terms of authorship. Mettmann considered the manuscript itself to be the youngest copy of the four, possibly from the start of the 14th century. Ferreira, on the other hand, considers it to be ‘the oldest surviving source’ from no later than 1280.

dataProperty.name: editionNotes
dataProperty.value: E1:The word nos is repeated on this stave in the manuscript, but is not assigned another note or ligature. E2:See E4. E3:This is a custos indicating the pitch of the note after the page break: these are commonplace in [To] but as far as I am aware this is the only one in [E]. By the way, all the custodes (pl.) in [To] have their stems down, so that's how they are rendered here, even though this one has its stem up in [E]. E4:Compare this odd-looking ligature (for one syllable) with the pair of separate notes at E2 in the refrain. E5:This line appears very faint in the manuscript facsimile. E6:The word a is repeated at the start of this stave, but is not assigned a note or ligature.

dataProperty.name: title
dataProperty.value: Afonso X, o Sábio: Cantigas de Santa Maria
